title: 109_s2205
content: The Act is titled the "Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006". It pertains to the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal. The Blunt Reservoir feature and Pierre Canal feature are defined in the Act as part of the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program. The Commission refers to the Commission of Schools and Public Lands of the State. Nonpreferential lease parcels are land parcels purchased by the Secretary for use with the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features. Preferential leaseholders are also defined in the Act. The term "preferential leaseholder" refers to a person or descendant holding a lease on a preferential lease parcel as of January 1, 2001. The term "preferential lease parcel" is a land parcel purchased by the Secretary for use with the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and the term "State" refers to the State of South Dakota. The term "unleased parcel" is a land parcel purchased by the Secretary for use. The Blunt Reservoir feature is deauthorized, and the State may accept ownership of certain portions of the feature with associated liabilities. The State may also agree to have the Commission act as the agent for the Secretary in administering the purchase option. The State may accept ownership of certain portions of the Blunt Reservoir feature with associated liabilities. The Commission may act as the agent for the Secretary in administering the purchase option extended to preferential leaseholders. Outstanding obligations shall inure to the benefit of the State. Conveyances to the State or preferential leaseholders shall be subject to reserved oil, gas, mineral rights, permits, licenses, and other outstanding rights. Conveyances to the State shall be subject to reservations by the United States and conditions specified in a specific Act. The Act of May 19, 1948 allows for the transfer of property to State agencies for wildlife conservation. Preferential leaseholders have the option to purchase the lease parcel from the Secretary or the Commission. The purchase can be made on cash terms equal to a specified amount. The Act of May 19, 1948 allows for the transfer of property to State agencies for wildlife conservation. Preferential leaseholders can purchase the lease parcel from the Secretary or the Commission at a specified amount, which is calculated by deducting ten percent from the determined value of the parcel. Preferential leaseholders can purchase the lease parcel with 10 percent down and the rest paid over 30 years at 3 percent interest. For parcels under $10,000, the purchase must be made in cash. Leaseholders have 5 years to exercise the purchase option. The value of the parcel is based on its fair market value for agricultural purposes. The fair market value for agricultural purposes of a parcel, determined by an independent appraisal less 25 percent, can be disputed and resolved according to regulations. If a preferential leaseholder fails to purchase a parcel within the specified period, it may be offered to the State of South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation. The South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks will receive land for wildlife habitat mitigation to compensate for habitat lost due to the Pick-Sloan project. Proceeds from land sales will be used to establish a trust fund for county taxes. The South Dakota Commission of Schools and Public Lands may allow land exchanges for nonpreferential lease parcels or unleased parcels at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal with the concurrence of the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. Priority for exchanges will be given to current lessees and adjoining/adjacent landowners. The United States reserves a perpetual easement for water conveyance structure as a condition of the land exchange at Pierre Canal. The United States grants an easement for a pipeline or water conveyance structure over the Pierre Canal. The government is released from liability for damages except for negligence. The Secretary will continue to lease parcels until they are conveyed. The Secretary will continue to lease parcels until they are conveyed under the terms applicable on the date of enactment. Within 180 days, the Secretary will provide the State with legal descriptions of all parcels. Archeological collections will be transferred to the South Dakota State Historical Society. $750,000 is authorized for expenses incurred in implementing the Act. Reimbursement for expenses incurred implementing the Act, not to exceed 10 percent of transaction costs.
